perturbation.original_text: 7.6 Late Payments. In the event that any payment due under this Agreement or the Supply Agreement is not made when due, the payment shall accrue interest from the date due at a rate per annum equal to [***] above the U.S. Prime Rate (as set forth in The Wall Street Journal, Eastern U.S. Edition) for the date on which payment was due, calculated daily on the basis of a 365-day year, or similar reputable data source; provided that in no event shall such rate exceed the maximum legal annual interest rate. perturbation.changed_text: 7.6 Late Payments. In the event that any payment due under this Agreement or the Supply Agreement is not made within *three (3) business days* of when due, the payment shall accrue interest from the date due at a rate per annum equal to [***] above the U.S. Prime Rate (as set forth in The Wall Street Journal, Eastern U.S. Edition) for the date on which payment was due, calculated daily on the basis of a 365-day year, or similar reputable data source; provided that in no event shall such rate exceed the maximum legal annual interest rate. The payment of such interest shall not limit a Party from exercising any other rights it may have as a consequence of the lateness of any payment.
perturbation.explanation: The original text states that interest accrues on payments not made 'when due'. The modified text specifies a grace period of *three (3) business days* before interest starts accruing. This introduces an in-text contradiction, as it is now unclear whether a payment is considered 'late' immediately upon the due date or after the three-day grace period. If, later on in the contract, there is a clause that indicates payments should be paid within a specific time frame, and this is not followed, there could be an in-text contradiction that creates uncertainty in enforcement. For example, there could be a penalty if payments aren't made in a timely fashion, or the other party could cease business operations until payments are made. The addition creates uncertainty in enforcement.
